div.bibl: Revyen, May 4, 1907. [ROOSEVELT CHANGES FRONT ON MOYER-HAYWOOD KIDNAPPING](Editorial)

body.p: President Roosevelt's uncalled for condemnation of the two labor leaders held in Idaho on a criminal charge (but not convicted) has caused so much indignation that the President himself found it appropriate to come forward with an explanation which, by the way, did anything but justify his statement. On the contrary, it shows that the President is not only apt to commit a terrible blunder in a moment of anger but that he also is too stubborn, cowardly and dishonest to admit his mistakes, and therefore attempts to worm away from the incident by means of eccentric arguments and false statements, all in order to save his face.

By arguing that the workers all over the country have taken sides with the accused men, he tries to hide his own mistake of joining their accusers. We would think that the workers of America, who sincerely believe in the innocence of their unfortunate trusted agents, should be free to make use of all legitimate means in order to save their comrades from the gallows

But Mr. Roosevelt does not find anything "undesirable" about the capitalistic tyrants roaming the hills and plains of Idaho and Colorado and terrorizing the

But this very attitude on the part of the ent did also serve to open the eyes of the workers. The case, originally scheduled for the purpose of crushing the Western Federation of Miners, served to raise and strengthen the brotherly feeling among the workers of the nation in a most excellent way, and might turn out to be a bad boomerang for the capitalistic bosses and their hirelings throughout the country.
